REQUEST HEADERS
// A unique ID which identifies each specific request.  Generated by the Postman application
Postman-Token: <a randomly calculated value>
// The hostname of the server.
Host: googleapis.com
// A string identifying the application used to make the HTTP request.  Since this RESTful request is generated by the Postman application, this is reflected.
User-Agent: PostmanRuntime/7.43.0
// The MIME type of the response that we (the client) are expecting to receive.
Accept: */*
// The binary data type that we (the client) can parse in the response.
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate, br
// Instructions on how to handle the network socket between the client and host.
Connection: keep-alive


RESPONSE HEADERS
// The MIME type returned by the server
Content-Type: application/json; charset=UTF-8
// Instructions to the client on how to cache the response for future requests
Vary: Origin
// Instructions to the client on how to cache the response for future requests
Vary: X-Origin
// Instructions to the client on how to cache the response for future requests
Vary: Referer
// The binary data type that has been returned
Content-Encoding: gzip
// The date for which this response is valid
Date: Tue, 28 Jan 2025 01:30:37 GMT
// Information about how the server handles requests
Server: ESF
// XSS is 'Cross Server Scripts', this is related to scripting attacks where a script is loaded from another server
X-XSS-Protection: 0
// 'Cross Frame Options', this is related to loading frames from other servers
X-Frame-Options: SAMEORIGIN
// Mime type options for content from other servers
X-Content-Type-Options: nosniff
// A custom header, looks like it contains information about SSL ports
Alt-Svc: h3=":443"; ma=2592000,h3-29=":443"; ma=2592000
// Information about encoding used in the transfer, large blocks of data will be split into chunks and transmitted
Transfer-Encoding: chunked
